channel.title: As others read us: American fiction abroad
channel.description:
This series analyzes European views of the works of American authors.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

image.title: As others read us: American fiction abroad

item.title: Sinclair Lewis, part one
item.description: In this program, the first of two parts, critics Renato Poggioli and Perry Miller discuss European opinions of American writer Sinclair Lewis.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: John Steinbeck, part one
item.description: This program, part one of two, explores European views of the works of John Steinbeck. Steinbeck himself speaks here, as do critics Edgar Lohner and Alexander Coxie.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: John Dos Passos, part two
item.description: In this program, part two of two, critics Maurice Coindreau and Harry Levin discuss the works of John Dos Passos, Dos Passos himself also speaks on the program.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Ernest Hemingway, part two
item.description: In this program, the second of two parts, critics Henri Peyre and Charles Fenton discuss the works of Ernest Hemingway.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: William Faulkner, part one
item.description: William Faulkner. Faulkner himself speaks here, as do critics Rene Girard and Carvel Collins.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: William Faulkner, part two
item.description: This program, part two of two, explores European views of the works of William Faulkner. Faulkner himself speaks here, as do critics Rene Girard and Carvel Collins.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Introductory program, part two
item.description: This program, part two of two, presents an introductory overview of the series, hosted by Robert Penn Warren and Claude-Edmonde Magny. The program also includes the voices of John Dos Passos, William Faulkner, John Steinbeck.
item.dc:creator: Magny, Claude-Edmonde, 1913-1966
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Thomas Wolfe, part two
item.description: In this program, the second of two parts, critics Adolf Klarmann and Maxwell Geismar discuss European opinions of the work of Thomas Wolfe.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: Wolfe, Thomas, 1900-1938

item.title: John Steinbeck, part two
item.description: This program, part two of two, explores European views of the works of John Steinbeck. Steinbeck himself speaks here, as do critics Edgar Lohner and Alexander Coxie.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: John Dos Passos, part one

item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Henry James, part two
item.description: In this program, the second of two parts, critics W.H. Auden and R.P. Blackmur discuss European viewpoints of the American author Henry James.
item.dc:creator: University of Massachusetts
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.dc:subject: Wolfe, Thomas, 1900-1938
